comments:
This course is an intensive introduction to various scientific perspectives on the processes through which people make decisions. Perspectives covered include cognitive psychology of human problem-solving, judgment and choice, theories of rational judgment and decision, and the mathematical theory of games. Much of the material is technically rigorous. 

Students said the class was “good” and “meaningful.” They really enjoyed this class as it made think about the decision-making of humans in different terms. Students commented that the structure of the class were slide presentations and then a discussion, unless it was an activity day. Students responded positively to the activity days.
	
Students said Professor Milkman was “generally great”, however many described Professor Milkman as “condescending” and “unwilling to hear other opinions.”

Some commented that Professor Milkman was a tough grader as it was really hard to get an A. Students who really enjoy reading Gladwell and Freakonomics are highly recommended to take this class.  Prior or current enrollment in STAT 101 or the equivalent, although not required, is strongly recommended.
